Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Encased Cantilevers for Ultra-Sensitive Force and Mass Sensing in Liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will improve the performance of encased atomic force microscopy (AFM) cantilevers, reduce their fabrication costs, and optimize their properties for next-generation scanned probe microscopy technologies. Atomic force microscopy is a workhorse technique for providing nanometer-scale information of materials, but its performance is compromised by viscous damping when operated in fluid. The encased cantilevers to be developed in this project significantly reduces damping, leading to high force sensitivity and performance which is identical to AFM imaging done in air. This aids quantitative interpretation of data and simplifies instrument operation. Encased cantilevers are a drop-in replacement, permitting the transformation of existing instruments into cutting-edge tools simply by exchanging the probe. The impacts of these products will be felt in fields from biology to clean energy to materials science.

The first technical objective of this research is to create new cantilever geometries that push the performance of our devices to the theoretical limits. The Phase I research resulted in a novel low-cost technique to fabricate encased cantilevers, thanks to the development of specialized semi-automated processing and quality control tools. The next technical objective of Phase II research is to further reduce fabrication costs by improving yields, increasing batch size, and implementing more manufacturing automation. We expect to demonstrate low-cost processing methods in which many high quality probes are fabricated efficiently. The third technical objective is to optimize these devices for next-generation scanned probe technologies including quantitative nanomechanical mapping, high-speed imaging and promising novel techniques such as photo induced force microscopy. At the end of the project period we will have optimized products specifically targeting these high growth applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF SBIR Phase II project developed encased Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) cantilevers. Today, many researchers struggle to perform liquid AFM reliably because the high viscous damping impedes quantitative interpretations of the tip sample interaction. The majority of biological samples have a low elastic modulus, which makes imaging and mechanical probing of biological samples with regular cantilever very challenging. Nevertheless, liquid AFM is a market driver because many biologically samples require liquid environment. Our proprietary and revolutionary innovation of encased cantilevers overcomes this problem. Building a hydrophobic encasement around the cantilever keeps it dry while immersed in liquids. Only a small part of the sensing probe interacts with the sample. Thereby we reduce damping and thermo-mechanical noise by more than one order of magnitude. The high quality factor enables quantitative interpretation of interactions and contrast mechanisms and also makes instrument operation easier enabling high quality liquid imaging by non-experts. 

The prohibitively high cost of our initial fabrication scheme for first prototypes was hindering widespread adoption of our revolutionary technology. In Phase I we have developed novel techniques that have already significantly reduced fabrication cost.  In our efforts to improve device performance, during the Phase II, we have accomplished the following. We optimized our processes for new cantilever geometries with tall tips to reduce squeeze film damping. We improved the reproducibility of the laser cutting using a picosecond pulsed UV laser. Further, we optimized an etch step such that cleanliness was improved and potential collapsing of the encasement can be entirely avoided. We discovered hydrophobic coatings for inside the encasement to maximally resist water nucleation. 

With this research, we invented two new aspects of device design that overcame the issue of evaporation and condensation of water in the encasement which has been a long standing challenge that resulted in variable device performance and even device failure over time. We protected this new intellectual property and licensed two patents from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.  In our efforts to reduce fabrication costs we focused on scaling to larger batch sizes and automating process steps. We created a large scale polymer deposition system. This tool is highly automated and can run processes at the push of a button. We developed a unique laser micromachining tool that uses image recognition and autofocusing to navigate between cantilevers to cut them with 500 nm accuracy. This unique tool is the workhorse of many of our demanding fabrication processes. Building these various fabrication tools, albeit more time consuming than initially predicted, allowed us to grow as a company and become independent of equipment at shared research facilities.

 The outstanding performance of product is demonstrated by imaging of DNA origami with the highest resolution yet obtained by AFM in liquid. We also developed electrostatic excitation for artifact free excitation of cantilever motion and demonstrated shielding that improves resolution in Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy. We have developed a close relationship with various microscope manufacturers these strategic collaborations help us market our products and provide valuable feedback on the customer’s needs.


 


Last Modified: 06/30/2019
Modified by: Dominik Ziegler
